Future mesoscale horizontal stirring in polar oceans intensified by sea ice decline
                    Gyuseok Yi 
            ORCID: orcid.org/0000-0002-8812-92251,2, June-Yi Lee 
            ORCID: orcid.org/0000-0002-3986-97531,2,3, Eun Young Kwon 
            ORCID: orcid.org/0000-0001-9165-41111,2, Sun-Seon Lee 
            ORCID: orcid.org/0000-0001-7403-64851,4, Myeong-Hyeon Kim 
            ORCID: orcid.org/0009-0008-5973-868X1,2, Wonsun Park 
            ORCID: orcid.org/0000-0002-6345-84281,2, Karl Stein 
            ORCID: orcid.org/0000-0002-2432-18671,4 & …Axel Timmermann 
            ORCID: orcid.org/0000-0003-0657-29691,4 Show authors

Nature Climate Change

(2025)Cite this article

Subjects
        
            Climate and Earth system modellingPhysical oceanography

AbstractMesoscale horizontal stirring (MHS) is ubiquitous in the oceans, influencing heat and carbon transport, phytoplankton blooms and fish larvae dispersal. The current generation of Earth system models lacks sufficient resolution to properly resolve MHS-relevant small-scale phenomena, such as oceanic mesoscale eddies, leaving it largely unknown how MHS will change in response to greenhouse warming. Here we determine how CO2 doubling and quadrupling will change the surface MHS statistics in Community Earth System Model simulations with 1/10-degree ocean resolution. MHS is analysed using the finite-size Lyapunov exponent, a Lagrangian diagnostic that measures the separation of close trajectories. Projected increases in MHS are expected in the Arctic Ocean and coastal Antarctic regions, driven by enhanced time-mean ocean flow and turbulence which predominantly result from sea ice reduction. The enhanced horizontal stirring in polar oceans implies substantial yet uncertain consequences for tracer transport, nutrient supply and ecosystems under higher CO2 conditions.

MainStirring is a turbulent process that deforms and stretches fluid elements into elongated filaments, thereby dispersing fluid properties and generating sharp gradients1,2. These gradients are smoothed by diffusion and, together with stirring, this leads to irreversible homogenization (mixing). In the ocean, where horizontal velocities dominate over vertical ones across most scales, mesoscale horizontal stirring (MHS) is the primary dynamical process. MHS is closely linked to mesoscale features such as eddies, meanders, fronts and filaments, which span tens to hundreds of kilometres and persist for days to months. It plays a pivotal role in regulating the transport of heat, carbon and other tracers3,4,5,6, phytoplankton blooms7,8,9,10, the dispersal of larvae and fish eggs11,12 and broader ecosystem interactions13,14,15.Given the wide-ranging impacts of MHS, understanding how MHS will respond to future climate change is particularly important in high latitudes, where warming is most strongly amplified. Recently, rapid sea ice decline due to greenhouse warming16,17,18 has driven major environmental changes in polar oceans, altering ocean temperature, salinity and surface momentum flux19,20,21,22, with potential consequences for diverse physical and biological processes23,24,25. Recent studies using state-of-the-art climate models have reported marked changes in upper-ocean circulation22 and a substantial increase in eddy activity26 in the Arctic under warming scenarios. Notably, a kilometre-scale high-resolution simulation showed a threefold increase in eddy kinetic energy (EKE) in the upper Arctic Ocean under a 4 °C-warmer climate, associated with enhanced baroclinic instability driven by sea ice loss26. Such dynamical changes are expected to markedly influence MHS. While a Lagrangian-based network theory study linked increased kinetic energy to stronger horizontal stirring in the Mediterranean under a warmer climate27, comparable analyses in polar regions are still lacking. Addressing this gap is crucial to improve understanding of oceanic responses to greenhouse warming in the most rapidly changing regions of the world.Here focusing on the polar oceans, we explore spatiotemporal changes in surface MHS under varying CO2 conditions. To characterize and assess changes in MHS, we use the finite-size Lyapunov exponent (FSLE)28,29, a Lagrangian diagnostic which measures the continuous exponential rate of separation between nearby particle trajectories, indicating how quickly a patch of passive tracers is stretched (Methods). The FSLE provides spatially and temporally resolved estimates of transport and mixing, revealing fine-scale features such as filaments and spirals that are often overlooked by Eulerian methods29,30. In this study, FSLE is calculated as the time-based growth rate of separation from an initial distance (δ0) to a final distance (δf), defined as a tenfold increase. To target mesoscale structure, δ0 and δf are set to 0.1° and 1.0°, respectively. This choice of δ0 aligns with the 0.1° horizontal resolution of the ocean model, while δf is set to a scale comparable to that used in previous studies28,31 for consistency (see Supplementary Information for δ0–δf sensitivity tests). The FSLE technique has been successfully applied to identify complex spatial and seasonal patterns of surface MHS in both the Mediterranean and global ocean under present-day conditions28,31.To investigate how future greenhouse warming affects MHS, we analyse idealized century-long time-slice simulations conducted using the fully coupled ultra-high-resolution Community Earth System Model v.1.2.2 (CESM-UHR)32,33,34, with horizontal resolution of 0.25° for the atmosphere and 0.1° for the ocean. Notably, in the Arctic the ocean model uses a tripolar grid with 2.5-km eddy-permitting resolution. The three experiments34,35,36,37 use constant atmospheric CO2 concentrations of 367 ppm (present-day, PD), 734 ppm (2 × CO2) and 1,468 ppm (4 × CO2) (Methods). Daily FSLEs, a measure of MHS, are analysed at each grid point over 10 years in each simulation. This approach enables evaluation of MHS changes under different CO2 conditions within a fully coupled ocean–sea ice–atmosphere framework. FSLEs from the CESM-UHR PD simulation closely match ocean reanalysis38 in both magnitude and spatial distribution (Supplementary Information), supporting the suitability of the model for this study.Surface MHS changes in polar oceansWe first examine surface MHS responses to varying CO2 forcing in the polar oceans by comparing daily FSLE snapshots at 15-m depth from the PD and 4 × CO2 simulations (Fig. 1a–d). The snapshots correspond approximately to the period of maximum sea ice extent—the vernal equinox (20 March) in the Northern Hemisphere and the autumnal equinox (22 September) in the Southern Hemisphere. At the vernal equinox of the first analysis year, Arctic FSLE fields show a marked intensification under 4 × CO2 relative to PD (Fig. 1a,b and Supplementary Video 1). FSLEs appear as filaments marked by local maxima, highlighting rapid separation of adjacent flow trajectories, especially at the edges of strong currents, vortices and meanders. Corresponding current speed snapshots (Fig. 1e,f) show that FSLE increases are most pronounced along major currents (for example, the Beaufort Gyre and Transpolar Drift Stream) and vortex boundaries across the Arctic. The greater prevalence of FSLE filaments under 4 × CO2 indicates marked MHS intensification driven by stronger mesoscale activity and mean flow. This intensification is probably attributable to a combination of factors, including increased momentum transfer to the surface ocean by wind in the absence of sea ice39 (Fig. 1i,j), enhanced eddy generation due to stronger upper-ocean baroclinic instability26 and reduced sea ice friction which would otherwise damp eddies40.Fig. 1: FSLE, current speed and sea ice concentration in the polar oceans under PD and 4 × CO2 conditions.a,b,e,f,i,j, Arctic Ocean snapshots of FSLE at 15-m depth (a,b), current speed (log scale) at 15-m depth (e,f) and sea ice concentration (i,j) from the PD (a,e,i) and 4 × CO2 (b,f,j) simulations at the vernal equinox (20 March) of the first analysed year (model year 130 for PD and model year 160 for 4 × CO2). c,d,g,h,k,l, Southern Ocean snapshots of FSLE at 15-m depth (c,d), current speed (log scale) at 15-m depth (g,h) and sea ice concentration (k,l) from the PD (c,g,k) and 4 × CO2 (d,h,l) simulations at the autumnal equinox (22 September). Credit: Basemaps from NASA Visible Earth (https://visibleearth.nasa.gov).Source dataFull size imageIn the Southern Ocean, daily FSLE snapshots at the autumnal equinox of the first year show a marked increase along the Antarctic periphery under 4 × CO2 relative to PD (Fig. 1c,d and Supplementary Video 2), coinciding with coastal regions where the Antarctic slope current (ASC) strengthens (Fig. 1g,h). As sea ice decreases in 4 × CO2 (Fig. 1k,l), the ASC within ~200 km of the coast strengthens by about 60% relative to PD. Similar changes are evident at subsurface depths of 75 m and 155 m (Extended Data Fig. 1), supporting the robustness of the 15-m results—the primary focus of this study. This depth minimizes direct wind and sea ice influences while capturing surface MHS patterns relevant to climate and ecosystems28.Probability density functions (PDFs) of daily FSLEs for each decade show a pronounced increase in polar ocean FSLEs. Surface ocean FSLEs generally follow a long-tailed, right-skewed distribution31,41,42, consistent with our results (Fig. 2). In warmer climates, the PDFs shift towards higher values, with the median moving rightwards, low values becoming less frequent and high values more common—changes that are statistically significant at the 95% level (Fig. 2a–c). This indicates stronger MHS, which accelerates the separation of nearby trajectories over broader areas and shortens the timescale to reach a 1.0° separation. The Arctic (Fig. 2a) shows most of its change from PD to 2 × CO2, with little further shift at 4 × CO2, reflecting CESM-UHR projections of a sharp sea ice decline under 2 × CO2 and near ice-free conditions for most of the year under 4 × CO2 (Extended Data Fig. 2a). The Southern Ocean (Fig. 2b) shows a modest PDF shift from PD to 2 × CO2, followed by a larger change from 2 × CO2 to 4 × CO2. This pattern differs from the gradual decline in sea ice extent observed throughout the Southern Ocean (Extended Data Fig. 2b) but aligns more closely with the progressive PDF changes seen in the Antarctic coastal region (Fig. 2c). Changes in the polar oceans are markedly greater than the minor shifts in the rest of the global ocean, where PDFs move only slightly rightwards, probably reflecting a balance between regional increases and decreases (Fig. 2d and Supplementary Information).Fig. 2: PDFs of FSLEs for the Arctic Ocean, the Southern Ocean, the Antarctic coastal region and non-polar oceans under different CO2 conditions.a–d, FSLE PDFs from PD (blue), 2 × CO2 (orange) and 4 × CO2 (red) in the yellow-highlighted regions: the Arctic Ocean (66.5–90° N) (a), the Southern Ocean (60–90° S) (b), the Antarctic coastal region (within about 200 km of the Antarctic coastline) (c) and the non-polar oceans (60° S–66.5° N) (d). Vertical solid lines denote medians. Wilcoxon rank-sum tests indicate significant differences (P < 0.05) between PD and both 2 × CO2 and 4 × CO2 in a–d. Credit: Inset basemaps from NASA Visible Earth (https://visibleearth.nasa.gov).Source dataFull size imageA comparison of decadal mean FSLE (\({\overline{{\mathrm{FSLE}}}}_{{\mathrm{h}}}\)) between PD and 4 × CO2 confirms a robust increase in surface MHS in response to greenhouse warming (Fig. 3a–d and Extended Data Fig. 3a–d), consistent with the snapshot comparison. This increase is also evident in 2-year means at 15-m, 75-m and 155-m depths, with decreasing magnitude at greater depths but similar spatial patterns (Supplementary Fig. 1). FSLEs are averaged using the harmonic mean (denoted by the subscript h), which is more appropriate for averaging rates of increase (Methods). The long-term mean FSLE changes reflect a combination of narrow features related to mean currents and broader turbulent structures driven by eddy activity (Fig. 3 and Extended Data Fig. 3).Fig. 3: FSLE, MKE and EKE under different CO2 conditions.a,b,e,f,i,j, The 10-year means at 15-m depth in the Arctic Ocean: FSLE (harmonic mean) (a,b) and square roots of the 10-year means of MKE (e,f) and EKE (i,j), for PD (a,e,i) and 4 × CO2 (b,f,j). c,d,g,h,k,l, The 10-year means at 15-m depth in the Southern Ocean: FSLE (harmonic mean) (c,d) and square roots of the 10-year means of MKE (g,h) and EKE (k,l), for PD (c,g,k) and 4 × CO2 (d,h,l). Credit: Basemaps from NASA Visible Earth (https://visibleearth.nasa.gov).Source dataFull size imageThese dramatic FSLE changes are also clearly reflected in the time series of domain-averaged FSLEs under PD, 2 × CO2 and 4 × CO2 simulations (Extended Data Fig. 4). In the Arctic, projected FSLE increases far exceed the amplitude of the PD annual cycle, which weakens under elevated CO2 (Extended Data Fig. 4a). This probably reflects the substantial loss of sea ice (dashed lines in Extended Data Fig. 4a) that drives seasonal variability in the present climate. As a result, interannual variability is expected to become more prominent. In contrast, the Southern Ocean exhibits a gradual FSLE increase along the Antarctic coast while the annual cycle remains relatively stable under warming (Extended Data Fig. 4b).Mean flow and eddy roles in MHS changesTo elucidate the relative contributions of mean flow and eddies to MHS changes, we analyse mean kinetic energy (MKE) and EKE, widely used Eulerian diagnostics31,42. While increases in horizontal stirring have been linked to MKE and EKE in the Mediterranean27, their roles in projected FSLE changes over polar oceans remain unexplored. Here MKE and EKE are estimated by decomposing daily horizontal velocities (\(u\), \(v\)) into mean components (\(\bar{u}\), \(\bar{v}\)) and eddy components (\({u}^{{\prime} }\), \({v}^{{\prime} }\)) using a 300-day high-pass filter43 (Methods). In both PD and 4 × CO2 simulations, decadal mean MKE exhibits localized maxima in narrow current bands (Fig. 3e–h), whereas EKE shows broader, more diffuse structures (Fig. 3i–l). The FSLE fields capture features of both but more closely resemble EKE patterns (Fig. 3a–d). Projected FSLE changes qualitatively follow changes in both MKE and EKE, as evident in PD versus 2 × CO2 and 4 × CO2 differences (Extended Data Fig. 3). For a quantitative assessment, we compute spatial correlations between decadal mean FSLEs and the square roots of the corresponding decadal mean MKE, EKE and total kinetic energy (TKE) at each grid point in the PD simulation (\({\overline{{\rm{FSLE}}}}_{{\mathrm{h}}}\) ~ \(\sqrt{\overline{{\mathrm{MKE}}}}\), \(\sqrt{\overline{{\mathrm{EKE}}}}\) and \(\sqrt{\overline{{\mathrm{TKE}}}}\); Extended Data Fig. 5a–f). FSLEs in polar oceans correlate more strongly with EKE than with MKE, consistent with previous findings27. The FSLE–TKE relationship is stronger in the Arctic but slightly weaker in the Southern Ocean, relative to EKE. For changes from PD to 4 × CO2 (\(\Delta {\overline{\mathrm{FSLE}}}_{{\mathrm{h}}}\) ~ \(\Delta \sqrt{\overline{\mathrm{MKE}}}\), \(\Delta \sqrt{\overline{{\mathrm{EKE}}}}\) and \(\Delta \sqrt{\overline{\mathrm{TKE}}}\); Extended Data Fig. 5g–l), FSLE changes correlate most strongly with TKE in both polar oceans, followed by EKE and MKE. The same ranking holds for 2 × CO2 minus PD, except in the Arctic where the FSLE–EKE correlation marginally exceeds the FSLE–TKE correlation (Supplementary Fig. 2). Overall, these results suggest that polar MHS intensification is driven predominantly by the increase in total current speed, reflecting combined mean and eddy contributions2.To clarify the respective roles of mean flow and eddies in shaping MHS, we performed additional FSLE calculations excluding either component. Specifically, we computed FSLE fields based solely on the mean flow (FSLEm) and solely on the eddy field (FSLEe) (Supplementary Videos 3 and 4), using a 300-day high-pass filter for velocity decomposition, consistent with earlier methodology. FSLEm exhibits sharper, more elongated filaments, highlighting organized vortices and meanders on larger spatial scales—an imprint of the slowly evolving structure of the mean flow. In contrast, FSLEe appears more chaotic and diffuse, closely resembling the full FSLE field (rows 1 and 3 of Extended Data Fig. 6). This contrast is also evident in the 2-year means (\({\overline{{\mathrm{FSLE}}}}_{{\mathrm{h}}}\), \({\overline{{{\mathrm{FSLE}}}^{{\mathrm{m}}}}}_{{\mathrm{h}}}\) and \({\overline{{{\mathrm{FSLE}}}^{{\mathrm{e}}}}}_{{\mathrm{h}}}\)): FSLEm shows localized high values, whereas FSLEe develops more uniformly, mirroring the spatial distribution of the full FSLE mean (rows 2 and 4 of Extended Data Fig. 6). Spatial correlations between FSLE and FSLEe (FSLEm) are 0.81 (0.61) in the Arctic and 0.84 (0.70) in the Southern Ocean (Supplementary Fig. 3), showing that mesoscale turbulence is the dominant driver of MHS, while persistent mean structures such as currents and perennial meanders also contribute locally.Potential drivers of surface MHS changesAs the previous section established a strong link between FSLE and TKE, understanding surface MHS changes requires examining both mean flow and eddies, along with their environmental drivers. In the Arctic, the most prominent driver under elevated CO2 is substantial sea ice loss, evident in the pronounced reduction of mean sea ice extent during the peak sea ice season (February–April) (Fig. 4a–c). Relative to PD, sea ice extent decreases by 62.4% under 2 × CO2 and by 92.8% under 4 × CO2. This sea ice loss leads to a substantial alteration in the long-term wind stress pattern (Fig. 4d–f) and an increase in wind stress magnitude (Extended Data Fig. 7). Wind stress here refers to the total ocean stress (\({\vec{\tau }}_{\mathrm{ocn}}\)), combining air–ocean (\({\vec{\tau }}_{\mathrm{ao}}\)) and ice–ocean (\({\vec{\tau }}_{\mathrm{io}}\)) components. Under PD, the wind stress pattern is spatially heterogeneous (Fig. 4d), but shifts to a more homogeneous and intensified anticyclonic pattern across the Arctic Ocean under 2 × CO2 and 4 × CO2 (Fig. 4e,f). Given the key role of anticyclonic wind stress in driving Arctic current systems (the Beaufort Gyre and Transpolar Drift Stream)44,45 and enhancing eddy activity22,25, this shift may be a primary driver of MHS intensification in the CO2-enriched world.Fig. 4: Sea ice concentration, wind stress curl and surface geostrophic current in the Arctic Ocean under different CO2 conditions.a–i, The 10-year means of the February–April peak sea ice season (FMA) sea ice concentration (a–c), wind stress curl (d–f) and surface geostrophic current (g–i) are shown for the PD (a,d,g), 2 × CO2 (b,e,h) and 4 × CO2 (c,f,i) conditions. In a–c, the lime-coloured contour lines represent the boundary of sea ice extent (sea ice concentration of 15%). In g–i, the magnitude is represented using shading (arrows for currents exceeding 0.05 m s−1). Sea ice concentration is the result of the sea ice component, while wind stress is an outcome of the ocean component. The mean sea ice extent in the Arctic Ocean during FMA has decreased by 62.4% (from 12.42 million km2 to 4.67 million km2) in the 2 × CO2 conditions (b) and 92.8% (from 12.42 million km2 to 0.89 million km2) in the 4 × CO2 conditions (c), relative to PD.Source dataFull size imageWind stress magnitude changes due to sea ice loss are assessed through projected changes in the momentum transfer rate from the atmosphere and sea ice to the ocean (Extended Data Fig. 7). Over sea ice-covered areas, \({\vec{\tau}}_{\mathrm{ocn}}\) is the sum of \((1-A){\vec{\tau }}_{\mathrm{ao}}\) and \(A{\vec{\tau }}_{\mathrm{io}}\), with A representing the sea ice fraction used as a weighting factor22,46. The contribution of each component to momentum transfer is evaluated separately. In CESM-UHR results, the annual mean momentum transfer rate by \({\vec{\tau }}_{\mathrm{ocn}}\) increases by 5.42% (2 × CO2) and 4.54% (4 × CO2) relative to PD (Extended Data Fig. 7a). Although these increases are modest compared with the extent of sea ice loss, a pronounced rise in \({\vec{\tau }}_{\mathrm{ao}}\)-driven momentum transfer—especially with strong seasonality—is projected (Extended Data Fig. 7b), while \({\vec{\tau }}_{\mathrm{io}}\) contributions decline (Extended Data Fig. 7c; see Methods for further scaling analysis). These changes suggest that enhanced wind stress over ice-free areas may also contribute to surface MHS intensification.Consequently, the Arctic Ocean exhibits intensified surface geostrophic currents (Fig. 4g–i) and strengthened MHS. Projected sea surface height (SSH) changes, from which these currents are derived, correspond well with Ekman transport shifts (Extended Data Fig. 8). Under both 2 × CO2 and 4 × CO2, wind stress enhances Ekman transport from the Chukchi and East Siberian Seas towards the central Arctic, while reducing transport from the Eurasian Basin towards the Canada Basin and the east coast of Greenland (Extended Data Fig. 8a–c). These shifts expand the high SSH region—formerly confined to the Canada Basin in PD—into the Eurasian Basin (Extended Data Fig. 8d–f). As a result, the Transpolar Drift Stream, flowing along the Lomonosov Ridge in PD, is projected to intensify and shift towards the Barents-Kara Sea (Fig. 4g–i). These sea ice-driven changes align with recent studies25,26, supporting their role in Arctic MHS intensification.In the Southern Ocean, FSLE increases under warming are most pronounced along the Antarctic periphery, where the westward ASC flows (Fig. 3c,d). This region features strong easterly surface winds (Extended Data Fig. 9a) that drive Ekman transport towards the coast, elevating SSH and inducing a meridional (cross-shore) pressure gradient that drives the westward geostrophic ASC47,48,49. While previous modelling study suggests that a poleward shift of westerlies may weaken near-shore easterlies and thus the ASC and Ekman downwelling50, CESM-UHR simulations under 2 × CO2 and 4 × CO2 show only modest changes in easterlies (Extended Data Fig. 9b,c), yet project substantial ASC intensification. This intensification is linked to substantial sea ice loss (Fig. 5a–c) and surface density reductions along the Antarctic coast (Fig. 5d–f), primarily due to freshening rather than warming (Extended Data Fig. 9d–i). The resulting enhanced cross-shore density gradient strengthens surface geostrophic currents (Fig. 5g–i), effectively compensating for the slightly weakened zonal wind (Extended Data Fig. 9a–c). Our findings highlight the stronger role of sea ice loss (Extended Data Fig. 10b), suggesting that further investigation is needed.DiscussionThis study uses a Lagrangian-based FSLE to characterize surface MHS in CESM-UHR simulations, focusing on the polar oceans with supplementary analyses for other regions (Fig. 6 and Supplementary Information). Simulations project substantial polar MHS strengthening under greenhouse warming, driven by intensified surface currents from both mean flow and eddies, represented as MKE and EKE (Fig. 6). In the Arctic, sea ice loss enhances MHS through wind stress changes; in the Southern Ocean, it induces coastal freshening that strengthens the ASC and, in turn, MHS. The PD simulation underestimates sea ice extent (Extended Data Fig. 2), probably underestimating Arctic MHS change. Antarctic sea ice projections are more reliable; however, the model does not include ice sheet dynamics. Credit: Basemaps from NASA Visible Earth (https://visibleearth.nasa.gov).Source dataFull size imageWhile we examined how surface MHS may respond to greenhouse warming, its consequent impacts on marine environments and ecosystems remain uncertain. Strengthened MHS in polar regions can reshape heat, carbon and tracer transport by modifying the relative contributions of mean circulation, Ekman transport and mesoscale eddy processes4,5. Moreover, MHS influences fine-scale vertical motions that regulate nutrient transport and shape phytoplankton distributions8,9,10,53,54. It can enhance production through submesoscale upwelling, but also suppress it by exporting nutrients offshore, as shown in coastal upwelling systems55. Yet, region-specific knowledge of how MHS controls nutrient supply and ecosystems under future climates remains limited, highlighting the need for further investigation. Such knowledge is particularly crucial in the Arctic, where rapid sea ice loss is likely to make the ocean seasonally navigable within decades56, increasing its importance for human activities and the urgency of understanding its changing environment.MethodsModel and data descriptionThe dataset used in this study was obtained from the ultra-high-resolution idealized greenhouse warming experiments conducted with fully coupled CESM-UHR32,33,34. The model has very high horizontal resolutions of 0.25° and 0.1° for the atmosphere and ocean components, respectively. This capability enables the model to resolve mesoscale dynamical processes in large parts of the oceans, such as eddies, meanders, fronts, filaments and so on.The CESM-UHR experiments include a present-day control run (PD) and two idealized experiments with CO2 doubling and quadrupling conditions (2 × CO2 and 4 × CO2)34,35,36,37. The PD simulation was integrated for 140 years from a quasi-equilibrated climate state33 with a CO2 concentration of 367 ppm. The 2 × CO2 (734 ppm) and 4 × CO2 (1,468 ppm) experiments were integrated for 100 years each (model year 71–170) after they split from year 71 of the PD experiment. The last quasi-equilibrated 10 years, excluding the final year for each simulation, are analysed to avoid climate drifts. The final year was partly used for Lagrangian tracking. The analysis period is from 1 January 130 to 31 December 139 of model year (10 years) for the PD simulation and from 1 January 160 to 31 December 169 of model year (10 years) for both the 2 × CO2 and 4 × CO2 simulations.To quantify the MHS at the surface ocean, we use daily mean \(u\) and \(v\) velocity fields at the second layer of the ocean model component of the CESM, Parallel Ocean Program v.2 (POP2)57, which corresponds to a depth of 10–20 m and has a central depth of 15 m. This study also analyses daily surface ocean current speed of the same layer and surface wind stress from POP2 and the sea ice model component of the CESM, Community Ice CodE v.4 (CICE4)58.Finite-size Lyapunov exponentThe FSLE is a powerful Lagrangian diagnostic and used to quantify the rate of separation caused by horizontal stirring28. Considering two particles in a turbulent fluid, initially separated by a distance δ0 and moving along distinct trajectories, we can model the growth of their separation δ(t) using the continuous exponential growth equation:$$\delta \left(t\right)={\delta }_{0}\,{{\rm{e}}}^{\lambda t},$$
                    (1)
                where the growth rate (\(\lambda\)) is the Lyapunov exponent59. The FSLE is a way to compute \(\lambda\) by explicitly defining spatial scales. The calculation begins by defining two scale factors of the initial and final distances (δ0, δf) between the two particles as finite values. Then, by using the Lagrangian tracking, we follow the movement of the two particles along the \(u\), \(v\) fields and calculate the FSLEs on the basis of the time \(\tau\) for δ(t) to evolve from δ0 to δf:$$\lambda (x,y,t,{\delta }_{\mathrm{0}},{\delta }_{\mathrm{f}})=\frac{1}{\tau }\mathrm{ln}\frac{{\delta }_{\mathrm{f}}}{{\delta }_{\mathrm{0}}}.$$
                    (2)
                This calculation is performed using the open-source Python program lagrangian 2.2.0 and the FSLE is determined by the maximum eigenvalue of the Cauchy–Green strain tensor, which is technically obtained through the Triplet method using three positional points (see section for ‘Code availability’).Since we are interested in mesoscale processes in the surface ocean, we computed the two-dimensional daily FSLE fields with δ0 and δf set to 0.1° and 1.0° (approximately 10 km and 110 km), respectively. To obtain the FSLEs for a single day at 12:00:00 UTC, the trajectories of the particles are integrated using the fourth-order Runge–Kutta method with constant 24-h intervals for a maximum of 360 days. If δ(t) is less than δf during the 360-day integration period, \(\lambda\) exists within the range of 0 and \({\lambda }_{360}\) (\({\lambda }_{360}\) is \(\lambda\) when \(\tau =360\) days). While other studies typically assume \(\lambda =0\) in this case, we assume \(\lambda ={\lambda }_{360}\) to avoid underestimation (Supplementary Fig. 4). The difference in results between the two assumptions—0 or \({\lambda }_{360}\)—is negligible, because \({\lambda }_{360}=\,\frac{1}{360}\mathrm{ln}10\approx 6.40\times {10}^{-3}\), which is close to zero.The FSLE technique can also be used to detect the Lagrangian coherent structures (LCSs)3,13,60 as well as the separation rate. LCSs can be categorized as either repelling or attracting based on the direction of trajectory integration used to calculate the FSLE. The forward-in-time FSLE integration identifies repelling LCSs (stable manifolds), while the backward-in-time integration reveals attracting LCSs (unstable manifolds). Although this study uses the forward-in-time FSLE calculations, it does not explicitly analyse LCSs. We focus solely on the separation rate of trajectories to quantify horizontal stirring. In this context, the choice between forward-in-time and backward-in-time FSLE makes no substantial difference28.Harmonic mean of FSLEsWhile previous studies have generally used the arithmetic mean, \(\bar{\lambda }\) (\(=\frac{1}{n}{\sum }_{i=1}^{n}{\lambda }_{i}\)), of the estimated FSLEs for temporal or spatial averaging, we primarily use the harmonic mean, \({\bar{\lambda }}_{{\mathrm{h}}}\) (\(=n/{\sum }_{i=1}^{n}\frac{1}{{\lambda }_{i}}\)), as it is more appropriate for averaging rates of increase (exponents). The two averaging methods produce different FSLE patterns (Supplementary Fig. 5), with the harmonic mean giving greater weight to smaller FSLE values than the arithmetic mean. Nevertheless, our overall conclusions are insensitive to the choice of averaging method.Computation of mean, eddy and total kinetic energyTo focus on the effects of oceanic mesoscale dynamics, we apply a 300-day high-pass filter43 to the \(u\) and \(v\) outputs of CESM-UHR simulations at 15-m depth to obtain the eddies (\({u}^{{\prime} }\), \({v}^{{\prime} }\)) (‘Code availability’). The mean flow (\(\bar{u}\), \(\bar{v}\)) is then obtained by subtracting \({u}^{{\prime} }\), \({v}^{{\prime} }\) from \(u\), \(v\). Here the 300-day cutoff approximately separates seasonal and longer-period variations into the mean flow. Subsequently, MKE, EKE and TKE are calculated using the following equations:$$\mathrm{MKE}=0.5({\bar{u}}^{2}+{\bar{v}}^{2}),$$
                    (3)
                $$\mathrm{EKE}=0.5({{u}^{{\prime} }}^{2}+{{v}^{{\prime} }}^{2}),$$
                    (4)
                $$\mathrm{TKE}=\mathrm{MKE}+\mathrm{EKE}.$$
                    (5)
                Wind stress scaling in the presence of sea iceWhen sea ice fraction (A) is not considered in the wind stress partitioning equation,$${\vec{\tau }}_{\mathrm{ocn}}=\left(1-A\right){\vec{\tau }}_{\mathrm{ao}}+A{\vec{\tau }}_{\mathrm{io}},$$
                    (6)
                the magnitude of two terms on the right-hand side can be roughly scaled from the quadratic drag law46:$${\vec{\tau }}_{\mathrm{ao}}={\rho }_{\mathrm{a}}{C}_{\mathrm{Da}}\left|{\vec{u}}_{\mathrm{a}}\right|{\vec{u}}_{\mathrm{a}}\,\left(\approx {10}^{0}\times 0.00125\times {10}^{0}\times {10}^{0}\approx 0.00125\right),$$
                    (7)
                $${\vec{\tau }}_{\mathrm{io}}=\rho {C}_{\mathrm{Di}}\left|{\vec{u}}_{\mathrm{rel}}\right|{\vec{u}}_{\mathrm{rel}}\,\left(\approx {10}^{3}\times 0.0055\times {10}^{-2}\times {10}^{-2}\approx 0.00055\right).$$
                    (8)
                Here the water density \(\rho\) is approximately 1,000 times greater than the air density \({\rho }_{\mathrm{a}}\): \(\rho /{\rho }_{\mathrm{a}}={\mathscr{O}}\left({10}^{3}\right)\). Additionally, the relative velocity between the sea ice and ocean current \({\vec{u}}_{\mathrm{rel}}\) (a few cm s−1) is about 0.01 of the surface wind velocity \({\vec{u}}_{\mathrm{a}}\) (a few m s−1): \(\left|{\vec{u}}_{\mathrm{rel}}\right|/\left|{\vec{u}}_{\mathrm{a}}\right|={\mathscr{O}}\left({10}^{-2}\right)\). The drag coefficients for the air–ocean CDa and ice–ocean CDi are 0.00125 and 0.0055, respectively. From the rough scaling of magnitude, \({\vec{\tau }}_{\mathrm{io}}\) is about 0.44 times of \({\vec{\tau }}_{\mathrm{ao}}\).

Published: 05 November 2025

Enhancing accuracy in identifying absorbing aerosol types and their radiative impacts
                    Kamran Ansari1,2 & S. Ramachandran1

npj Climate and Atmospheric Science

volume 8, Article number: 351 (2025)
            Cite this article

Subjects
        
            Atmospheric scienceClimate change

AbstractAerosol radiative forcing is highly uncertain due to an imprecise quantification of absorbing aerosol type which is most critical. Lack of accurate measurements and characterization of aerosol absorption results in this aerosol parameter being poorly constrained and highly underestimated in climate models. In the methods used earlier to classify aerosol absorption a large fraction remained unidentified. A new classification method, that overcomes these limitations, is developed by leveraging the spectral characteristics of aerosol optical depth (AOD) and single scattering albedo (SSA) of different absorbing aerosols, which remarkably reduces the contribution of unidentified aerosol type to almost nil globally, demonstrating the robustness and enhanced accuracy of this new method. On a global scale, black carbon (BC) and the associated absorbing types dominate contributing >70% annually, Dust and Mixed-Dust contributing the rest. The absorbing aerosol types exhibit quite distinct spatial and seasonal variations. This improved and innovative classification of absorbing aerosol types offers significant potential for advancing research in climate modeling, satellite retrieval, and aerosol-monitoring applications, and will be key to reduce the uncertainty in radiative and climate impact of aerosols.

IntroductionAerosols significantly contribute to altering the energy balance of the Earth-atmosphere system, hydrological cycle, temperature structure, and atmospheric stability through aerosol-radiation and aerosol-cloud interactions1,2,3. However, an accurate estimation of aerosol impact on the radiation budget is very challenging, and confidence in the quantification of aerosol influence on climate change is still low2. Thus, aerosols give rise to the largest uncertainty in the accurate quantification of the present and future climate due to lack of observational constraints on optical and physicochemical properties of different aerosol types especially the absorbing ones, and their accurate representation in climate models3,4,5. Aerosol types over a region are governed by the long-term average of optical, physical, and chemical properties of aerosols, and thus, accurate identification of aerosol types is vital6,7,8,9,10. One of the major causes behind the high uncertainty in aerosol radiative forcing (ARF) is associated with aerosol absorption, which is a smaller fraction of aerosol extinction but is the most critical parameter for quantifying ARF2,11. The lack of accurate global measurements and characterization of aerosol absorption results in this aerosol parameter being poorly constrained and highly underestimated in climate models in various regions across the globe, particularly over Asia12,13,14,15. The mixing of absorbing aerosols can enhance the absorption efficiency of composite aerosols and thus it can substantially affect the aerosol radiative effects and impose a significant challenge in ARF estimation16,17,18. Therefore, precise identification and quantification of different absorbing aerosol types are not only essential for satellite retrievals and climate models to enhance the accuracy of radiative and climate impact assessment of aerosols but also for their sustained mitigation and control of emissions7,10.The distinct characteristics of spectral single scattering albedo (SSA) and size parameters of different absorbing aerosols (e.g., black carbon (BC), brown carbon (BrC), and dust), can be utilized to potentially identify the dominant absorbing aerosol types using remote sensing and in situ measurements. Studies have utilized several combinations of predictors of two aerosol optical parameters using ground-based Aerosol Robotic Network (AERONET) observations and created a 2-D identification cluster space to classify absorbing aerosol types by choosing threshold values such as fine mode fraction (FMF0.50) vs. Ångström exponent (AE0.44–0.87)19,20,21,22,23, FMF0.50 vs. single scattering albedo (SSA0.44)19,20,21,24, FMF0.50 vs. absorption AE (AAE0.44–0.87)19,20,21,25, AAE0.44-0.87 vs. extinction AE (EAE0.44–0.87)25,26, AE0.44–0.87 vs. SSA0.4427, and AE0.44–0.87 vs. single scattering co-albedo (1-SSA0.44)28. Some major drawbacks associated with the 2-D identification space are that in some spaces, either SSA was not included or, if it were included, it was only for a single wavelength, and the threshold limits of classified absorbing aerosol types in some spaces overlapped with each other thereby reducing the accuracy of those classification schemes and the classified types. Further, none of these classification schemes include absorbing carbonaceous aerosols (CA) (= BC + BrC). The previous studies applied the respective classification scheme over a few particular sites and/or a region, however, when applied globally, a large fraction of aerosols remained unidentified over many sites, indicating that the applicability of these classification schemes is restrictive and valid only over a particular region. About 35% of the absorbing aerosol types remained unidentified globally in a recent study29 that used the combination of spectral SSA and AE for aerosol classification (did not contain CA in its classification scheme), and furthermore, the unidentified type fraction was even higher over many sites. A new classification scheme is developed that overcomes the limitations and the uncertainty in the traditional classification methods for absorbing aerosol types, which resulted in a large uncertainty in ARF. This scheme, which utilizes the spectral features of AOD and SSA, is able to quantify 98% of absorbing aerosols globally (Figs. 1–3) (Methods).Fig. 1: Classification scheme for absorbing aerosol types.a Single scattering albedo (SSA0.44) vs. extinction Ångström exponent (AE0.44–0.87) for different aerosol types (dust, mixed, urban-industrial (U/I) + biomass burning (BB)) (Table 2). b Spectral variation of SSA for the classified absorbing aerosol types (Dust, Black carbon (BC), Carbonaceous aerosol (CA), Mixed-Dust, Mixed-BC, and Mixed) from all sites (Table 2). Total number of data points and % contribution of each absorbing aerosol type are given in brackets. Variation of c imaginary part of refractive index (IRI) at 0.44 µm with IRI average at 0.675–1.02 µm, and d real part of refractive index (RRI) at 0.44 µm with RRI average at 0.675–1.02 µm for each classified absorbing aerosol type. Vertical dashed lines in c, d indicate the average IRI (0.675-1.02 µm) and average RRI (0.675–1.02 µm), respectively, below which 95% of data points lie in each panel. Colors in a, c, d represent the probability density function computed by kernel density estimation (KDE), ranging from lower (blue) to higher (red) density.Full size imageFig. 2: Flowchart for the classification scheme of absorbing aerosol types.a Flowchart for the classification scheme for the identification of absorbing aerosol types of Dust, black carbon (BC), carbonaceous aerosols (CA), Mixed, Mixed-BC, and Mixed-Dust by utilizing the extinction Ångström exponent (AE) (for segregating fine, coarse, and mixture of fine and coarse aerosols) and spectral feature of single scattering albedo (SSA). Regional variation of the contributions of absorbing aerosol types after varying AE for fine (AEFine) b and coarse (AECoarse) mode aerosols c by ±0.1 and ±0.2 from their actual values of 1.4 and 0.6, respectively.Full size imageFig. 3: Global, and contribution of absorbing aerosol types over Asia, Australia, and Americas.a Contribution (%) of classified absorbing aerosol types (Dust, Black carbon (BC), Carbonaceous aerosols (CA), Mixed, Mixed-BC, and Mixed-Dust) over the globe (annual and seasonal). b Global annual mean contribution of absorbing aerosol types for different slope SSA thresholds for a consistently decreasing SSA: > 0 (base case a), 0.01, 0.02, and 0.03. Annual mean contribution (%) of absorbing aerosol types over c Central Asia, South Asia – I and – II, Southeast Asia, East Asia, and Australia, and d West North America, East North America, Central America, and South America.Full size imageResultsClassification scheme for absorbing aerosol typesThe SSA indicates the magnitude of aerosol absorption. BC, the strongest absorber per unit mass, has higher absorption in the near-IR range and its spectral SSA shows a decreasing gradient over regions where BC is the dominant absorbing aerosol7,29. BrC has highly wavelength-dependent absorption and has strong absorption in the near-UV range which decreases in the visible range (>0.4 μm)30. Whereas, dust absorption increases in shorter wavelengths (UV and short visible) and decreases in longer wavelengths, and thus, SSA for dust increases with wavelength7,29. Distinct spectral variations of SSA of these absorbing aerosols can be used to classify the absorbing aerosol types, however, spectral features of SSA of BrC and dust can overlap with each other due to their similar absorption tendency with their higher values of imaginary part of refractive index (IRI) toward near-UV wavelengths31,32,33. Absorbing CA ( = BC + BrC) is mostly present in fine mode, and dust dominates in coarse mode size range33. Thus, for the classification of absorbing aerosol types, AE values are first used to segregate fine and coarse mode aerosols (Methods, Fig. 2a). It is important to note that both spectral SSA and AE (exponent of spectral AODs) are independent of each other, which are used here to determine the thresholds of AE values for fine and coarse mode aerosols to enable the classification of various absorbing aerosol types.The dust-dominated sites contain moderately absorbing aerosols (core density area of SSA: 0.88–0.94) and include mostly coarse mode aerosols (AE: 0.02–0.33) (Fig. 1a). Whereas for mixed aerosol types the distribution contains two distinct dense areas with the first in lower AE range (AE: 0.39–0.67) and relatively high absorbing aerosols (SSA: 0.86–0.90) than the second which lies in high AE range (AE: 1.03–1.52, SSA: 0.88–0.96). The distribution of biomass burning (BB) and urban-industrial (U/I) aerosol types contain mostly fine mode aerosols (AE > 1.4) and a wide range of SSA varying between 0.84 and 0.98 which include both high (mostly emitted from BB) to low absorbing (mostly emitted from U/I) aerosols7,10. Uniformly increasing and decreasing SSA spectra are found in Dust and BC absorbing aerosol types, respectively (Fig. 1b). However, the spectral average SSA is higher for Dust type (0.95) than Mixed (0.91), CA (0.91), and BC (0.89) types. Spectral SSA for Mixed and Mixed-Dust types are lower than Dust type SSA. This indicates an increase in the absorption of mixed aerosols, resulting from the internal mixing of dust with other absorbing aerosols in mixed aerosols23,29. A lower IRI in 0.675-1.02 μm (knir) (0.0036) in Dust type reveals lower absorption in higher wavelengths and higher absorption only at 0.44 μm as most of the data points are above 1:1 line in Dust type (Fig. 1c). Whereas, for Mixed, Mixed-Dust, and CA types, dense core area of knir lie in higher range which shows that the absorption of these types is relatively higher than Dust type in 0.675–1.02 μm wavelength range. Dust type encompasses relatively lower absorbing aerosols (higher SSA) and lower spectral real part of refractive index (RRI) likely associated with aerosol hygroscopic growth in high relative humidity levels (Fig. 1d)34,35. For BC type, IRI is higher for all wavelengths (knir = 0.0315), and most of the points are around 1:1 line. Thus, it is clear that this new scheme is able to classify different absorbing aerosol types using the spectral feature of SSA and the size distribution of various absorbing aerosols, and their magnitude of absorption (spectral IRI values) matches well with the intrinsic absorbing characteristics of different absorbing aerosols present in each absorbing aerosol type.Using this classification scheme, nearly all the known absorbing aerosol types are identified and contribution of the unidentified is quite small (mean: ~2%). However, contribution of unidentified type can be higher for a specific site but overall, even in those sites, contribution of the unidentified type is <10% (Figs. 3–5). In contrast, previous methods, using 2-D space with threshold discrimination19,20,21, reported a much higher unidentified type contribution, reaching ~30% at a few sites in Saudi Arabia21 and the global average of unidentified type was estimated to be ~50%. Similarly, the unidentified type contribution was estimated to be ~35% in other methods29. In stark contrast, the new classification scheme is able to provide a much better and robust quantification of different absorbing aerosol types and reduces the unidentified type to almost nil (2%) on a global scale.Fig. 4: Contribution of absorbing aerosol types over Europe.Same as Fig. 3c, but for Europe.Full size imageFig. 5: Contribution of absorbing aerosol types over North Africa, South Africa, and Middle East.Same as Fig. 3c, but for North Africa, South Africa, and Middle East.Full size imageGlobal distribution of absorbing aerosol typesThe selected AERONET sites are considered representative of their respective regions despite the limited number of sites in a few regions (e.g., South America, South Africa), as they collectively cover the broader spatial extent and have been utilized in previous regional aerosol assessments36. To minimize the bias in global assessments caused by the comparatively dense network of sites in Europe and North America, the global averages reported in this study are not derived from the mean of all 126 AERONET sites. Instead, global mean is computed as the mean of 14 regional averages, ensuring equal weight is assigned to each region (Fig. 3a). Further, over a few high-latitude sites in East North America and Europe, data points during winter are relatively fewer compared to other seasons (Table 1). However, it is found from previous studies36,37 that the seasonal variabilities in aerosol properties (e.g., AOD, SSA) over the high-latitude sites in East North America and Europe are found to be low and not statistically significant. Thus, the uneven temporal sampling (e.g., limited winter data in high-latitude sites) is not expected to affect the reliability of seasonal comparison.Table 1 Total observational counts and mean (± standard deviation) aerosol optical depth (AOD at 0.50 µm) and absorption AOD (AAOD at 0.50 µm) on annual and seasonal scales over different regions across the globe during 2015–2019Full size tableBC dominates the aerosol absorption on a global scale as the single largest type contributing 30% or more throughout the year, followed by Mixed and Mixed-BC. The BC and the associated types including the CA dominate the global aerosol absorption type (≥70%) while Dust and Mixed-Dust contribute the rest during the year (Fig. 3a). The absorption due to Dust type contribution increases in spring and summer to 15% when these particles increase. On a global-mean scale, the annual- and seasonal-mean contributions of different absorbing aerosol types are quite similar (Fig. 3a), varying within 10% between seasons. However, the absorbing aerosol types show quite distinct spatial and seasonal variabilities (Figs. 3–6). Dust type is dominant over Central Asia (42%) and western South Asia – I (e.g., Indo-Gangetic plain (IGP)), as the observation sites in these regions are located near dust sources (e.g., Taklamakan, Aralkum, and Thar deserts, and western arid regions of Arabian Peninsula) (Fig. 3c). Dust contribution is higher (~60%) during summer over Central Asia due to dust transport from the above dust sources (Fig. 6a). Dust type contribution gradually decreases from west to east IGP. However, the Mixed type increases over the central and east IGP region and becomes the dominant type (~50%), followed by Mixed-BC type due to high human influenced emissions along with the seasonal (spring and summer) transport of dust37,38.Fig. 6: Annual and seasonal variations of absorbing aerosol types and their corresponding AOD and AAOD.a Annual and seasonal mean % contribution of absorbing aerosol types across the globe. Same for b AOD and c AAOD (at 0.50 µm) corresponding to different absorbing aerosol types.Full size imageIt may be noted that an independent validation of the present classification scheme using in situ chemical composition measurements is challenging for several reasons. First, most available in situ studies are based on surface-level measurements, while vertical columnar observations, which are more relevant to our classification based on column-integrated aerosol properties, are limited. This makes direct comparison between in situ surface and columnar measurements infeasible. Secondly, absorbing aerosols typically constitute a minor fraction of total aerosol loading, making it difficult to obtain detailed number concentration (more directly linked to columnar extinction over mass concentration) measurements for individual absorbing species from existing studies. However, results from this classification scheme are compared with previous classification methods and Generalized Retrieval of Atmosphere and Surface Properties (GRASP)/Component retrieved columnar mass concentration using the AERONET dataset, and the results are found to be consistent, supporting the reliability of our methodology as detailed below. The present findings are consistent with mixed aerosol type found over the IGP derived using previous classification schemes7,10,39. It also aligns with high columnar mass concentrations of all absorbing aerosols over the IGP retrieved from the GRASP/Component algorithm40. GRASP/Component algorithm computes the columnar mass/volume concentration of various aerosol species (e.g., BC, brown carbon, non-absorbing insoluble, absorbing insoluble, non-absorbing soluble, and aerosol water content). Whereas our classification scheme provides the absorbing aerosol types and identifies the dominant absorbing aerosol present in the atmosphere. As these two approaches estimate different parameters — GRASP providing columnar mass/volume concentration values for multiple species and the other (present study) assigning a dominant absorbing aerosol type — a direct one-to-one numerical comparison between them is not straightforwardly applicable, and it is quite challenging. Nevertheless, to provide an independent, albeit qualitative, verification, the spatial distribution patterns of the absorbing aerosol types from our classification are compared with the corresponding species retrieved from the GRASP algorithm. This comparison, showed broadly consistent spatial and seasonal patterns as seen above, supporting the practical utility of the new classification scheme.On a regional scale, Mixed type is dominant over South Asia – I annually (~50%), and the contribution of Dust type (~30%) increases during spring and summer due to the transport of dust aerosols by strong westerly winds (Fig. 6a)37,38. The increase in CA type (27%) over Pokhara (an urban/metropolitan site in the Himalayan foothills) is due to the influence of agro-residue and forest fires41. A small fraction of CA type (7%) is observed over rural sites of Gandhi College and Lumbini, which are affected by agro-residue burning. In South Asia – II, the contribution of Mixed-BC type is higher in all seasons (40–60%) (except summer due to wet scavenging and suppression of burning activities42). The BC absorbing type is higher over Karunya_University (30%) than MCO-Hanimaadhoo (5%, an island) as this site is located in an urban city (Coimbatore). Dust type in South Asia – II increases during summer and it is negligible in other seasons (Fig. 6a).Forest fires of tropical rainforests and slash-and-burn agricultural activities in Southeast Asia give rise to significant amounts of CA and BC types in all sites (e.g., Luang Namtha, Silpakorn Univ) (Fig. 3c). Forest fires and agricultural burning over Southeast Asia are active during dry seasons (winter and spring), and they start in mid-winter and intensify during spring43. Thus, the regional contributions of BC and CA types are higher (30-50%) during winter and spring over Southeast Asia (Fig. 6a). It is consistent with high columnar mass concentrations of BC and BrC found over Southeast Asia40. In addition, a significant amount of BC type (~50%) is observed over urban-populated sites such as Penang and Singapore in Southeast Asia. Mixed absorbing aerosol type is dominant (35–60%) over western sites in East Asia (e.g., East China) as these sites are affected by dust aerosols from the Gobi and Taklamakan deserts in addition to anthropogenic emissions44, and columnar mass concentrations of all absorbing aerosols are found to be high as well40. Whereas, Mixed type decreases and BC type increases over eastern sites in East Asia. BC, Mixed, and Mixed-BC types are present (~20–45%) with a small contribution of CA type over Taiwan, and this feature is almost similar for all sites in Taiwan. Jabiru (a rural site in Australia) is affected by biomass burning emissions and dust (during summer) which leads to higher contribution of BC and Mixed types, followed by CA and Dust types45.The BC type is dominant (>65%) over East North America as most sites in this region are influenced by U/I aerosols dominated by fossil fuel emissions, and less by emissions from biomass burning and dust (Fig. 3d). Mixed type is slightly higher (15%) over central and southeast parts of North America compared to the eastern part of North America, nevertheless, this region is dominated by BC type. On a regional scale, the contribution of BC type exceeds 50% in all seasons over East North America (Fig. 6a), which is consistent with a previous study where columnar mass concentration of BC was found to be higher than other absorbing aerosols over the same region40. The contribution of fine mode aerosols is relatively lower over West North America compared to East North America due to dust transport from arid regions (such as Mojave and Sonoran deserts) in addition to anthropogenic emissions from urban populated sites37,46. Thus, the contribution of Mixed type, followed by Mixed-BC type, is higher over West North America, and this feature over West North America is consistent in all seasons (Fig. 6), revealing the contrast in the dominant absorbing aerosol type between East and West North America (Fig. 3d). Mexico City (in Central America) is one of the largest urban megacities in the world where high population and human activities along with its meteorology and topography significantly impact the local air pollution47. These capital sites are influenced by anthropogenic emissions and by transport of dust originating from the Puna-Altiplano desert, which becomes more prominent in summer as the subtropical jet stream strengthens50.
